awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Cost-effective manufacturing to enable adoption of a novel nutrient-dense chickpea dough platform in mass-market processed foods
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to develop an alternative for high-calorie, nutrient-poor, palatable foods. This proposal will create a nutritionally dense ingredient portfolio, based on a novel chickpea dough, with broad application in processed foods. The set of ingredients will consist of crunchy, high-protein, higher-fiber, and low-calorie ingredients with broad applicability in the processed food space; this could potentially impact population health, including prevalence of type II diabetes, obesity, and their co-morbidities. Such a change in ingredient sets will also result in a large commercial impact of this research. Economic benefits include the development of new products, brands, production and processing equipment to optimize the use of these novel, chickpea based, nutrient dense ingredients. 
 
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project focuses on the evaluation of a novel chickpea dough to create a nutritionally dense ingredient portfolio with broad application in processed foods. Generally, foods produced with nutritionally dense ingredients have strong flavors and poor acceptance, but alternatives require processing that is slow, inefficient, and costly.  To solve this challenge, we are evaluating a novel microwave technology. The goals of the proposed innovation include: identification of formulations and processing parameters for several ingredient applications, demonstration of consumer sensory acceptance, and validation of scale-up viability through cost analysis. Technical goals include: Prediction modeling of heating patterns and identification of shapes, sizes, and ranges of processing parameters; drying trials to identify a versatile dough formulation for multiple applications; shelf stability tests; consumer acceptance tests to prove market viability; and nutritional analysis to fully characterize the final products.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Antithesis Foods is developing a portfolio of nutrient dense and affordable ingredients to help people eat healthier by making better-for-you foods that also taste good. Our goal is to produce crunchy nutrient dense ingredients from legumes that are high in fiber and protein and have the same taste and texture as commonly found commercial counterparts made from commodity crops such as wheat, potato, rice, and corn. Nutritionally dense ingredients typically have strong flavors and tastes that are not broadly accepted, in contrast to nutritionally poor yet neutral-flavored ingredients. In addition, the incorporation of higher quality, nutrient-dense ingredients is expensive, due to the unique processes required to make them acceptable as ready-to-eat (RTE) products. Our innovation lies in a novel formulation and processing strategy that imparts unique functionality to our legume-based doughs, producing the desired crunch while simultaneously masking off flavors. Due to its neutral flavor and malleable shape, the dough can be formed and used in multiple applications such as croutons, chips, toppings, cereals, bars, confections, as inclusions in other products, and as crunchy snacks, while supplying greater nutritional value than traditional counterparts.

 

In Phase I, Antithesis developed a proof-of-concept legume-based ingredient platform with customizable with broad application in processed foods. Prior to Phase I, we had developed a technology that produced neutral-tasting chickpea-based spheres with a wheat-like crunch. However, the processing method necessary to achieve these desirable final qualities was lengthy, costly, and not scalable. This Phase I project focused on ways to reduce product costs through various processing methods, expand our technology into an ingredient platform, and demonstrate commercial interest through partnerships with large food manufacturers.

 

The major results we achieved in Phase I to demonstrate overall feasibility of our legume-based ingredient platform were: 

-         Proved the feasibility of using vacuum microwave drying (VMD) to create expanded chickpea-based ingredients;

-         Identified and sourced functionalized ingredients to impart favorable macronutrient profile and/or beneficially modify product texture, including texturized pulse proteins and a small percentage of waxy and native starches that allow us to switch to a chickpea powder that is 66% cheaper per pound;

-         Achieved a 73.6% reduction in drying time utilizing the vacuum microwave process and 64.8% reduction using convective drying in comparison to our pre-Phase I drying process;

-         Showed that ingredient protein and fiber content can be increased by up to 33-35% of total product mass, a factor of about 2x in comparison to pre-Phase I formulations, while still maintaining desirable texture, allowing us to customize macronutrient profile for specific applications;

-         Developed 24 unique viable products for ingredient platform from 4 base formulations, 3 form factors, and 2 drying processes;

-         Confirmed consumer acceptance through sensory tests in which pre-Phase I spheres were outperformed by Phase I products in every category and product prototypes earned a purchase intent up to 79%;

-         Demonstrated scalability of ingredient platform through preliminary manufacturing tests and cost analysis that showed a reduction in ingredient cost from $0.03 per gram to $0.005-0.007 per gram;

-        Validated commercial viability of B2B business model through strategic and pilot partnerships and secured product development projects with major CPG companies.

 

The above outcomes demonstrated both the technical and commercial viability of the Phase I project.
